results.title: Decision for chemistry
results.creator_credit: MPO Productions, Monsanto Chemical Company and Sidney Meyers
results.brief_description: Demonstrates the importance of the chemical industry and its role in everyday living. Mentions the development of fire-resistant materials, treatment of soil with phosphates and Krilium products; the use of detergents in the laundry industry; the development of new textile fibres; and research on radio-active materials. For modern youth, with an enquiring mind, wonderful opportunities for a worth-while career are offered by the chemical industry.

results.title: Decision Australia
results.creator_credit: Kingcroft Productions, Bank of New South Wales and John Kingsford-Smith
results.brief_description: A promotional film aimed at British residents. Shows an English family who have applied to emigrate to Australia under the Assisted Passage Scheme. Shows the many attractions of Sydney.

results.title: Deciding to organize
results.creator_credit: Bonnie Sherr Klein and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Organizing for Power”.
Produced as a part of the Challenge for Change Program, this series examines Saul Alinsky’s method of organizing communities into effective action units based on participation democracy. A group of concerned citizens from Dayton, Ohio, consult Alinsky on means of creating an effective organization.

results.title: Deciding a future
results.creator_credit: UNICEF, William Hetzer and Edward King
results.brief_description: UNICEF believes that a well organized and involved community that mobilizes itself for a change is performing a needed activity. This program shows how community participation has become an active means of development in Lima, Bangkok and New York.

results.title: Decidedly out of this world
results.creator_credit: Joan Rossi and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: In 1939, Prime Minister Menzies announced that Britain was at war with Germany and that, as a result, Australia is at war with Germany. Joan Rossi talks about how she joined the army in 1941 and subsequent training, her work as a Syphon Officer, moving to Brisbane and tells of how she decoded the sinking of the ship Centaur. Post war, Joan still helped out at RAAF, helping other women find work before finding her own job and settling into post war life

results.title: Decide to be safe
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Personal Side of Safety”.
Shows that safety comes with decision. Points out that the worker must decide to be safe and build up a reserve of safety knowledge on what to do in any situation.

results.title: Deception
results.brief_description: This evocative subtitled work is beautifully framed enhancing the depiction of its black yet familiar themes which are further supported through considered use of narrative pace, attention to lighting and effective use of special effects.

results.title: Decent exposure
results.brief_description:
Decent Exposure evolved from the belief that art should be confronting, stimulating to those who view it. The video was an attempt to take the concept and give it concrete form. The basic plot is that art escapes en-masse from galleries and confronts people on the streets. Its left up to the cops to stop the “escapee” art from terrorising the population but to do that they have to capture the ringleader, The Expert.
The Expert is a sculpture of an art critic, a middle aged man in underpants (based on Peter Corlett’s The Connoisseur, currently in the Ian Potter Museum) struck in a judgemental pose as though he is forming a pompous opinion of an artwork.
The story was set in contemporary Melbourne (1990). Those dreary consumerists who now dominate the inner suburbs were already beginning to invade our fragile but energetic Fitzroy and St Kilda art communities. The dead hand of conservatism and bureaucratic centralisation was already being felt.
The plot ambitiously, but rather awkwardly, strove to shout to the world that, ‘the Emperor has no clothes”. In 1990 the Pyramid bank crash had just happened. The government is so on the nose electorally that party officials start moves to recruit The Expert, who has become a charismatic figure to the media. They intend him to replace the Treasurer.
Somehow I convinced journalist Jim Schembri (who bore a striking resemblance to the sculpture) that playing The Expert would be a good idea. His accepted his costume (a pair of Y front undies) with a look of trepidation.
The highlight was Jim running through the St Kilda Esplanade market, with the camera hidden 50 metres away, on a busy Sunday morning proclaiming to those he ‘confronted’ that he was a sculpture who was, ‘living, breathing art” - the great thing is that Jim was, for that moment, being accurate.

results.title: Decent exposure
results.brief_description: Numerous paintings and sculptures escape from the National Gallery and start terrorising the streets of Melbourne. “The Expert” who encouraged the artworks to escape in order to expose themselves to the public then puts himself on the campaign trail. Features the filmclip “Keep on trying”.

results.title: December bride
results.creator_credit: Little Bird, Film Four International, Central TV, British Screen, Jonathan Cavendish and Thaddeus O'Sullivan
results.brief_description: Unfolding against the rolling contours of the beautiful Ulster coastline Thaddeus O’Sullivan’s film is a brooding and stunningly photographed drama of broken taboos within the harshly repressive atmosphere of a turn-of-the-century Presbyterian community. Sarah is the servant girl left alone on the Echlin farm with brothers Hamilton and Frank. Her subsequent pregnancy outrages local minister Sorleyson when she refuses to name the father or marry either of the two men. But can she find a way of living with the consequences that neither ostracises the family completely nor runs against her steadfastly independent principles.
